Interesting. Randomness can be a powerful tool, for example in statistics. If you have a random sample, you can deduce information about the population as a whole. I seem to recall that the Roomba works on randomness: rather than trying to calculate the best way to clean a room, it just randomly makes decisions about direction and eventually cleans the entire floorspace. I have also read that one can randomly select a set of stocks and thereby perform similarly to the S&P, and certainly better than fund managers.

Perhaps teenagers are simply enacting that age-old human weakness: disparaging that which one does not understand, thus protecting oneself from change. We all know how that ends up.
Ah, Miss Ley, I look forward to your comments on all subjects; however when you comment on language, you are brilliant by every definition I know.

Mr. Sante,
It is not by 'Random', as defined in the 16th century to mean “haphazard,” something “without aim, purpose or fixed principle” that I came across your article on 'Not One of Us'.

Seldom a word that I use, it was news to hear that it had many different meanings, and that I am still living the days of Shakespeare. One of the reasons I am commenting is that I am a Narcissist sufferer, and to the honest, I feel badly because you have so few comments when an article on how to barbecue ribs this weekend gets 101.

Today a man just told me that he and his daughter enjoyed meeting me and that I was eccentric, following by the inevitable addition that I must know this. There was a slight pause. This might work in my favor or backfire, although I get plenty of smiles in the street and pats on my elderly crown.

The best short story about one 'meaning' of random, you will find in 'The Moabitiss' by Gallant. Call it random if you like, but I got quite a surprise when reading it today before your article, and it is a brilliant reminder that things are not always what they appear to be at first sight.

Sentences such as: 'They are not quite our kind of people', 'I do not belong to their Tribe', and a select few others are deplorable, and this is when it comes in handy not to fit in anywhere, and to be invited everywhere. Even the most stoic of us do not like to be considered as an 'Afterthought' and pleased to confirm you are not a 'rando'. Perish the thought.
To Richard Bucci in Binghamton, from Binghamton:  I think "mistaken" or "overzealous" would be better than "disingenuous", which entails deception.

Artist 85
Alas, Ambrose Bierce known as 'Old Bitters', the author of How to Write it Right, would be having a field day and probably win a Nobel Prize for Literature suitable for all generations. 'Talented for Gifted', he writes, 'These are both past participles, but there was once the verb for gift, whereas there was never the verb "to talent". If Nature did not talent a person the person is not talented'.

Our English teacher in France was trenchant in my days of the joys of school about the use of 'gotten', and perhaps randomly it was always 'I saw a rabbit IN the road'? It was always Duck in the singular and there was never mention of fruit in the plural. The latter perhaps because an apple a day has now been expanded to dates, kiwis, peaches and a variety of creamy sauces.

You can imagine that I am no expert either but a source of irritation to my nervous system is the usage of sentimental scatological humor, but I won't go on a ramble here, while remaining dubious that you are random.

David Bee
The primary definition of "random"? To each his or her own interpretation and language changes with the times that we change.

Mr. Jeffries,
Thoughts on financing.
Depending on repatriated corporate money is a one time thing that doesn't satisfy the "we're in this together" spirit of the social contract. Since the preponderance of k-12 funding comes from local property taxes, we must find a different source.

1) Everyone must contribute without exception. I suggest a federal education tax on gross income, graduated so that anyone who has income, earned or not, pays at least a token amount.

2) It can be argued that American business will benefit by having a deep pool of qualified people from which to recruit. Business should pay its share, also calculated on gross revenue. It will build a base of consumers and workers.

Calculating the revenue required should be easy. After a few years, rates will stabilize although there should be flexibility in the rate so that the education fund always is sound and fully funded.

Something that won't be popular with those owing education loans: The program should be in place and funded before relief is given on prior loans. Loans generated to pay for private, certainly for-profit private schools at any level should not be paid from the education fund. However, every effort should be made to recover from institutions that defrauded their students, at least 100% of tuition and fees paid by injured students.

It's going to be contentious designing a program that will work for the long term. We owe it to ourselves to get it right.

Ireland is not the United States. A referendum might appeal to romantic democrats with numbers on their side, but civil rights never ought to be subjected to totalitarian referendums just because voters have anti-freedom numbers on their side, for we have a Constitution unknown in Ireland. Our Constitution is supposed to protect the civil rights of individuals from popular infringement by voters. Even where courts sometimes tortuously find otherwise. If one does not like the Constitution, one cannot and need not schedule an election when one’s rights are infringed. It is a hard-earned constitutional lesson which the carefree do not like or do not understand. They might understand the lesson if voters wrongly took away their pet liberty.
This one, too!

I have always had a soft corner for relativity, not least because one of my scientist heroes showed the world that the right perspective is necessary to arrive at the true, if counter-intuitive, way in which nature works.  I am sure there is a lesson here for dealing with social and political issues.  Condemn zealotry by all means.  But put matters in perspective.  If local transgressions pale in comparison to atrocities in a distant land, censure the former, but don't ignore the latter.  We are one species sharing an ever shrinking and ever more fragile planet.

Or, since the Christian Church has lasted 2,000 years, it could be that the Catholic Church will give up defending its male only hierarchy and make changes as great as those made after the Reformation. Creating a church that will be a force for love and not hatred centuries into the future.
... and finished. Church attendance is below 15% and 51% of the population are religiously unaffiliated. My generation (going in to their 30s) are 90% unaffiliated.

Lastly - as it's late, and standing in that Dublin Castle courtyard for hours was tiring - it's interesting to note that the Catholic leader in Ireland said tonight that the result showed that the church needs "a reality check".

In essence, a countdown started at about 7pm in Dublin tonight, counting down to 20 years in the future, when the Catholic Church in Ireland could very well be a spent force in largely secularised state. If the Church has lost/is losing The Youth Voice today - and a huge amount of young people in Ireland voted yes today - they're unlikely to return to the flock. If they remain disengaged, their children, down the road, are also likely to add to the cycle of fewer and fewer Catholics, or practising Catholics in any meaningful number.

Skip forward a generation - 20 years - and the impact of losing the disinterested, diametrically opposed younger people of today creates an abyss at the heart of the church in Ireland. In effect, if the church doesn't get a handle on reversing the followers it's losing, and has already lost in Ireland, then it could effectively lose Ireland - and all in just one generation, just as just one generation ago (almost) homosexuality was still illegal in Ireland, and there was precious little public empathy or support for gay people.

That's one hell of a reality check for the church to have to face now, but tick-tock - the countdown has already started...
We could do a lot worse than have you run for president, David.  Great to see your picture with Bill.

Geeze Frank, I do not have any PAC money supporting me, do not get paid to make speeches, do not have a charitable foundation, have a clean record, and a modest retirement account, that does have equities from several large companies, but that can be placed in trust.

Have a good education, plenty of worldly experience, so what is to stop me from running for one of the higher offices. If I follow your advice, I could do it for free, and everyone would know who I am, and what my policies would be.

Maybe we could do it like in Jefferson's time, tack posters to trees, and send letters to town criers, would that do it? All I would need is a good writer like Ben Franklin, and a few other cronies like Alexander Hamilton. Of course the populace would just fall all over themselves to vote for me.

As far as I can tell, the Clinton's have done very well giving speeches, and running a foundation. I have not seen what kind of income they get from the foundation, but I did get to hear Bill at UC Dais a few weeks ago, and I can see why he gets paid well to speak. Not only that, he is a natural born ham. He came down to meet the crowd, took my camera and had an aide, take a picture of me and my wife with him posing in it.

I can not express just how much I appreciated that. The only other president or ex president I can remember being public friendly , was Truman, who took his morning walks in SF during the UN meeting.

"don't get drunk"

Josh?

I've been really drunk a few times in my day. My wife does a face plant after one large glass of wine. Yeah, it is better not to do that. But I'd never dare get on my high horse and say it like this.

My daughter is 22. We've talked about this. So far, she really hasn't gotten drunk. But I'm not relying on that as a final answer.

Good judgment, just like defensive driving, is an aspiration but not a certainty.

What we set up must be safe for someone who does something foolish. I have, and one day no doubt she will too.

"Mop up repeat offenders" is really what our justice system does in most cases. We mustn't fool ourselves about reality. That would be small comfort for my daughter or for me if she was number 5 on the way to the mop up.

Her dorms had emergency call buttons seemingly everywhere. Her workplace has some very attentive security people. When some guys followed her home, the police came in response to her cell phone call. Constant care by everyone is the only way, like these things.

We still must not railroad the innocent to get the guilty in the net. But the attention to prevention will provide evidence even if it fails, so it will not be mopping up after too very many.

The political discussion in this essay points to one direction. It is not the direct worship of money. It instead points to the worship of the accumulation of money. The quest of obtaining riches is what is viewed as holy.

Our society has adopted a new religion, the worship of wealth accumulation. Wealth accumulation has supplanted some ancient need for royalty, for tribal chiefs. We place these people on pedestals and look up to them as if they were special, or have special powers and therefore deserve special treatment. We don't question how they made the money or what they do with it. We just believe that since they have it, they must deserve enhanced treatment.

This worship forms the catalyst for behavioral relativity. Whatever they have, or have been paid, their morality is not in question because someone else has received more. The doing is not questioned. Only the being matters and that is being super rich.

We treat market capitalism as if it were a divine calling. Making money is a holy quest. But capitalism is inherently amoral. Business has no conscience. This forms the basis of a social contradiction.

This contradiction drives the kinds of people that run for public office and the reasons why we vote for them. We are getting exactly what we asked for. The types of people that should run for office never do and even if they did, no one would notice.
